etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in George M'Gowan (b. 1853). From German Pyridon from Pyrid- (in Pyridin) + -on

definitions: Each of three isomeric keto derivatives of pyridine, differing in the position of the oxygen atom; any substituted derivative of such a compound.

notes.text: Formula: C₅H₅NO. The pyridones exist in equilibrium with their corresponding tautomers (hydroxy derivatives of pyridine).
